intro: Carlomohria carolina, commonly known as the Carolina carolinate, is a rare flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its blooming period occurs in late spring to early summer, producing white to pale purple flowers that attract pollinators. Due to habitat loss, Carlomohria carolina is considered endangered and is protected in several states.
